did.unittitle: Philadelphia Museum of Art Johnson Collection binders

bioghist.p: Corporate lawyer and art collector John G. Johnson amassed a seminal collection of over 1,200 European paintings and sculptures between the early 1880's and his death in 1917. In Johnson's will, he left his art collection and his home at 510 South Broad Street to the City of Philadelphia, and named the Pennsylvania Company for Insurances on Lives and Granting Annuities as trustee of his residual estate. A 1917 codicil of Johnson's 1912 will mandated that the collection remain installed in his home unless an extraordinary situation should arise making a move necessary. As early as 1919, only 2 years after Johnson's death, legal proceedings began, and by 1921 an official petition was placed before the Orphans' Court of Philadelphia for permanent relocation of the Collection and the sale of the 510 S. Broad St. property. The plea was grounded in the fact that the cost of renovation that the property would necessitate in order to safely house the Collection would be in excess of the available funds. The petition was dismissed, and the City proceeded with renovation projects to the extent afforded by the limited budget. By 1933, the Depression had added an overwhelming burden to the maintenance of the deteriorating property. An informal proposition to display the Collection at the Philadelphia Museum of Art was then approved by the Court. Subsequently, the property was sold and the Trustee of the Collection entered into a lease agreement with the Museum. The Johnson Collection was to be displayed and stored at the Museum in concordance with Museum hours and operations. The Trustee was responsible for rent payments and providing guardianship for the Collection as well as paying maintenance costs, including contributions to the general Restoration Fund of the Museum. The Trustee would continue its role as custodian and administrator of the Collection. In 1926, Henri Marceau was appointed assistant curator of the Johnson Collection. Two years later he was promoted to curator. He also maintained a position as an assistant professor at University of Pennsylvania's School of Fine Arts from 1925 until 1929, when he took on the additional role of Curator of Fine Arts at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. In 1933 his position at the Museum was revised to Curator of Paintings, and then to Chief, Department of Paintings and Sculpture in 1937. At this time Marceau also became Associate Director, and then took on full directorship of the Museum from 1955 to 1964. Marceau maintained his role as Curator of the Johnson Collection throughout these various appointments, and beyond them, until his death. Under the auspices of the Pennsylvania Company, and with the assistance of Barbara Sweeny, Marceau oversaw the relocation and installation of the Collection in the allocated galleries and storage spaces at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Marceau and Sweeny organized several exhibitions featuring works from the Johnson Collection including "Flemish Painting," "Vienna Art Treasures" and "Flanders in the 15th Century," as well as overseeing reinstallations of the Johnson galleries. The team also oversaw the revision of the original Italian and Dutch and Flemish catalogues, published in 1966 and 1972 respectively, and the production of a Book of Illustrations in 1953. They continued together as the curator and associate curator of the Johnson Collection until Marceau's death in 1969, upon which Sweeny assumed Marceau's position of curator until 1972.

scopecontent.p: Materials include: photographs, catalog descriptions with curator's notes, exhibitions, publication, and provenance information, correspondence, permission to publish requests, research and reference materials including, offprints, extracts and xeroxes of articles, and conservation and restoration files. One lateral drawer of photos used as proofs in Italian Paintings 1250-1450, in the John G. Johnson Collection and the Philadelphia Museum of Art, by Carl B. Strehlke.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
